questions.question_text: Joe, an employee at a large regional bank, wants to receive company email on his personal smartphone and tablet. To authenticate on the mail server, he must first install a custom security application on those mobile devices. Which of the following policies would BEST enforce this requirement?

discussion.content: Using a non company owned device for work is considered BYOD. It doesn't really matter where the device is located.

I think this falls under DLP (Data Loss Prevention) policy because since the employee has corporate information on his phone and the phone so happens to be lost or confiscated by a bad actor the data on the phone would have to be encrypted or remotely wiped somehow. This is just my perspective and analysis but I'm going with DLP on this one.
How would downloading work email on a personal phone be related to BYOD policy? He may not even bring that phone or tablet to work. Just keep it at home. So then, what would it be?

THE ANSWER IS NOT "A". THE ANSWER IS "C", ALL DAY -- EVERY WAY!
Engineering staff has 6 users.
engineering subnet = 192.168.1.64/29; /29 means 3 host bits, block size = 8
thus subnet mask = 255.255.255.248
Network ID= 192.168.1.64
First host ip= 192.168.1.65
Last host ip= 192.168.1.70
Broadcast ID= 192.168.1.71

Next network address= 192.168.1.72

That provided answer is a joke

I think the answer should be C... if they are sub-netting even further 192.168.1.64/29 wold be the start of a new sub net with 8 address 6 usable after you take out the id and broadcast making it 192.168.1.70...the answer A just added 55+6 on the default sub-net for the remote office. the way i read the question it is asking for the engineering sub-net... am i wrong?

I still think the question is written really badly. Why would you mention the digital department when they don't ask you to calculate anything related to that department. Also why say using the least amount of IP's when they have already given you the CIDR notation anyway?

The answer is C. 192.168.1.70.
The engineering subnet is 192.168.1.64/29.
Ip range for subnet is: 192.168.1.64-192.168.1.71
192.168.1.64 - subnet IP address
192.168.1.71 - broadcast IP address
Usable IP addresses:
192.168.1.65-192.168.70
Last usable IP address is 192.168.1.70.
This question make me wonder of other questions might be wrong...
"A"would be the answer is the question had been the last usable ip address for the digital marketing subnet.

Answer is C,@ 192.168.1.64/29 leaves us with just 3 host bits since 29 is already dedicated for the network bits. Now 2^3 = 8 addresses - 2 (1 for the net id and 1 for the broadcast). .64 is the net id so the 1st usable add is .65 up to .70, .71 is reserved for the broadcast. Since the engineering team has 6 members then .65 ~ .70 will suffice. Then .70 would be the last usable add. for the engineering team. Cheers!
Use a subnet calculator if not sure .. answer is C
So when I wrote it all out, I got 192.168.1.70 for the last valid host. Which is C.
Answer is C
It's definitely C
CIDR calculator says : First IP 192.168.1.64, Last IP 192.168.1.71 so last usable host is minus one from last IP so C should be answer.

Answer is C, as D's .71 will be the broadcast ip
https://ip.rst.im/ip/192.168.1.64/29
I agree with answer being C.
I'm thinking, the sub is .64 , and you are adding another 8 ids, out of which 6 can be used. So, 64 is network id, and 72 is the broadcast id, then you have the last one .71 hence D w'd be correct.

comments.content: .72 would be the network ID of the next SN (64 + 8 = 72), so .71 would be the BC ID and .70 would be the last usable host.

discussion.content:
The answer is C. 
A is not on the same subnet

questions.question_text: A technician is allocating the IP address space needed for a new remote office. This office will contain the engineering staff with six employees and the digital marketing staff with 55 employees. The technician has decided to allocate the 192.168.1.0/24 block to the remote office. The engineering staff has been allocated the 192.168.1.64/29 subnet. Using the LEAST amount of space possible, which of the following would be the last usable IP address in the engineering subnet?

discussion.content: Had to be C because other users in the same area (but in a different direction from the AP) could connect fine. Probably using a uni-directional or patch antenna.

" Other users across the hallway can connect and use the wireless network properly."
After seeing the answer, it makes more sense now. Meaning people in the opposite direction have good access.
Why is the answer C?

comments.content: The signal strength is 5% which means the AP and/or WNIC has the wrong antenna type. A,B, & D do not account for poor signal.

discussion.content:
The correct answer is A. PRI.
PRI is the standard for providing telecommunication services to enterprises and offices. It is based on T-carrier (T1) transmission in the US, Canada, and Japan, while the E-carrier (E1) is common in Europe and Australia.
The T1 line consists of 23 bearer (B) channels and one data (D) channel for control purposes.
The E1 line consists of 30 B-channels and one D-channels.
The Primary Rate Interface channels are typically used by medium to large enterprises with digital private branch exchange (PBX) telephone systems to provide digital access to the public switched telephone network (PSTN).
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Primary_Rate_Interface
A T1 circuit provides 23 concurrent B channels and 1 D channel for signaling. A PRI can run on either a T1 or E1 circuit, so the answer is correct.

comments.content:
correct- PRI (Primary Rate Interface): A type of ISDN that uses 23 bearer channels and one
64-Kbps data channel, represented by the notation 23B+D.

discussion.content: Also, T1 is not a PSTN connection. PRI and BRI are PSTN connections.

questions.question_text: A VoIP system will require 23 concurrent voice channels and one signaling channel. Which of the following types of WAN service would provide the BEST connectivity to the PSTN?

discussion.content: I disagree. I think the answer is C.
A rollback plan is exactly what it sounds like. It's a list of steps you'd take to undo a release and restore the system to its original state. so yes (C) is the correct answer
definitely C. Believe me, I know this one

comments.content: The key word is 'in case of a failure"
That's multiple words... You can't fool me!
"use in case of a failure" <-- If you have a failure, you use the rollback plan.
If you have a failure you use a rollback plan, if you have a disaster you use a business continuity plan.

discussion.content: The answer should be D. The key word is "upgrade" not update.

questions.question_text: A network administrator is going to be performing a major upgrade to the network. Which of the following should the administrator use in case of a failure?
